text: Slightly opalescent golden colour, moderate sized creamy off-white head; aroma of grapefruit, peach, some grape, and biscuit notes; taste is the same with significant bitterness; easy to drink and refreshing

Gravity Cask Half Pint at Craft 100 Festival at Craft Beer Co, Clapham, London in April 2014 - Yellowy Gold in colour. Very Fruity; zesty grapefruit citrus, tropical fruit. Hoppy; piney hops. Bitter citrus and tropical fruity throughout. Increasingly bitter into the dry finish. Very tasty for low ABV. Decent. (2014-04-05)
Half Pint on keg at Cheltenham Real Ale Festival. Pours a clear gold with a small white head. Hoppy aroma, hints of citrus. Bitter throughout, grapefruit, floral.
Decent easy drinking sweet grapefruit and nice aster taste. On tap at the Baum rochdale.

At St Albans Real Ale Festival, pours a clear golden colour. The smell is white wine, lightly toasted malt, a bit fruity. The taste is dry, toasted malt, white wine ending quite dry. Light in body with mild carbonation.
Cask at Hopinn, Newcastle Under Lyme. Pours golden amber with off white froth. Nicely hopped, single hop golden. Some citrus, not too bitter. Decent.

Cask at The Holy Inadequate, Etruria. A clear golden colour with a thin white head. Aroma of grapefruit, peach, some grape and floral hops. Taste of grapefruit, peach, some orange, slight berry fruitiness and floral hops. Light bodied and a soft carbonation. A dry, crisp, grapefruit bitterness in the finish. A citrusy, hoppy golden ale. Punches well above it strength, really nice.

50cl bottle at home from beerritz.co.uk. Body is clear pale, head is small, white, mostly diminishing, good lacing. Nose is orange, flavor is honey, floral, parfume, grapefruit. Medium to heavy sweet, light bitter. Finish is long lasting hoppy heavy bitter, watery sidetaste. Light to medium body, thin texture, average carbonation. Easy, very refreshing, excellent fade from sweet taste to bitter finish.

Cask at the Southampton Arms on 5th April 2015. Just-off-clear blonde with off-white decaying head and part lacing. Fruity aroma and liquid with grapefruit and grassiness, the latter of which dominates an increasingly bitter finish. Light texture and body. A fine ale from Mallinsons.
Bottle at home. Pours golden amber, nose is grapefruit, orange, taste is similar, juicy fruit.

Backlog rating. Bottle from Beer Ritz. It pours a slightly hazy golden color with a medium of-white head. Aroma is yeasty, with notes of hay, earth, wet grass, black pepper, light funk and citrus peel. Taste is yeasty and spicey, with dried apricots, earth, citrus, grains. Light body with lively carbonation. Overall, decent

Cask Drovers Rest Monkhill. Crystal clear pale gold beer, with that beautiful NS aroma. Gorgeous dry yet jammy/marmalade flavour, fresh prickly grapefruit finish and at 3.8, one you could drink all day.
Cask kings head Huddersfield. Golden good white head lace as ude expect from brewer. Light grassy citrus aroma. Taste is citrus grassy decent sweet malts light hoppy bitters. Medium body. Ok stuff

Cask at the Euston Tap, 04/11/14.
Clear golden with a well appointed off white covering.
Nose is lightly skunked hops, pissy, bitter citric rinds, mandarin, straw.
Taste comprises more semi skunko hop notes, lemon rind, tangerine, straw, earthy, light mineral.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close with a nice skunky wash.
Solid golden blonde, one of the better ones out there, a sincere GB!
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Cask @ Old Gate, Hebden Bridge. Straw-blonde with a creamy-frothy head. Its a dry hopped ale with light citrus lemon and grapefruit flavours.
Bottle shared with Mr_H a clear pale golden ale straw coloured with a frothy white head taste is grapefruit and lemon sharp bitter finish decent f

500ml bottle from Drygate, Glasgow (3.9% abv on the bottle label) - hazy golden (due to bad pouring) thin white head, grapefruit, citrus aroma, minimal lacing, citrus flavour, dry bitter finish, well balanced

500ml bottle from Beer-Ritz, Leeds. Pours a light hazy golden yellow, thick white head. Light citrus aromas, hint of green grape. Taste is light bitter, more grapefruit end of citrus. Light body, creamy texture. Abrupt finish. Not bad.
A very pale beer with a mild, floral aroma. Its rather like a less in-your-face citra, I think. Quite mellow and would be perfect as a session beer on a sunny afternoon.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2016 500ml bottles from The Real Ale Company, Valhallas Goat & Drygate (3.9% abv). Pale golden yellow, not much head. pineapple grapefruit grain aroma and flavour. Leafy citrus pineapple aftertaste. Light and refreshing. A perfect golden ale.

500ml bottle from BeerRitz online store. Hazy yellow-gold colour, white foam head leaving good lacing and aroma of tropical fruits, mango, floral citrus, hoppy. Taste is biscuity malt balanced with juicy fruity mango, passionfruit, orange, with hop resin, grapefruit, lingering bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation, dry finish with biscuity notes and tangy bitterness. Very drinkable.
Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. This hazy golden beer pours with a large foamy head. It has floral fruit and bitter citrus flavours followed by notes of grapefruit on the finish.

500ml bottle. Golden shade with fluffy white head. Pillows of white grape, citrus and straw in the aroma. Orange pith, sherbet and a slightly sharp bitterness to the taste. Something a bit vegetal about it though. Quite light in body with above average carb. Started out well but went a bit astray, good though.

Clear gold with fluffy white head, gooseberry and raspberries on the on the nose, medium body, gentle carbonation, red berries and a bitter finish.

Cask conditioned at Birmingham Beer Fest 13. Gold with white head. This certainly does showcase the Nelson Sauvin hop clearly. The beer is crisp with little malt impact, its all about the hop, not one of my favourites but there is a clear gooseberry skin note with a wine like background flavour, just a hint of tartness in the hop flavour. It does exactly what it sets out to do.

22nd December 2012Lightly hazy gold beer, good white head. Palate is light and crispy. Mild minerals. Nice fresh grapey Nelson Sauvin. Mild marmalade bitterness and a little grapefruit. Finishes crispy and semi dry. Decent and no blinking Mallinsons soap in this one.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2013 500ml bottle. Pours cloudy pale straw colour with a good white head. A little less sediment than many of Mallinson?s offerings. A little more grain on the nose than expected, with good fruit and yeast aromas. As one reviewers have pointed out, not too complex. Perhaps a touch watery to begin, leads to tropical fruit, yeast and an intensely bitter hoppy grapefruit finish. Light bodied with moderate and very fine carbonation. Not massively ?interesting? but lovely all the same.
Lovely bitterness to begin, and then fades into a satisfying sup. Lacking complexity but we all love a bit of simple now and again, eh Bish?
Quality golden. Lacking complexity as they all invariably do, but solid fruity hoppy bitterness that provides pleasure to last drop.
Cask at Stourbridge Beer Festival; clear amber pour with soapy white head, fruity aroma, grapefruit taste some citrus fruits, bready malts, excellent low ABV golden.

Cask at The Anchor, Digbeth, Birmingham. Poured a hazy light amber with a bubbly white broken head and lots of lace. The aroma is surprisingly rather fruity. The flavour is medium bitter, hoppy and a little spicy, but rather smooth on the palate with lots of citrus fruits. The bitterness does stay around for a while in the aftertaste. A super session beer.

50cl bottle from Westholme Stores, Goring. The initial pour resembles a good pilsner, pale straw with a loose white head; but the sweet grapefruit aroma immediately proves that this is not the case; in the mouth theres an explosion of tart, fruity, grapefruit with a grainy body; and a sharp, zesty, citrus note that carrys through into a gloriously bitter finish. This is absolutely splendid stuff - why cant every low strength golden ale taste this good?

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2014  Bottle from Jacks, Westholme Stores, Goring-on-Thames, Oxon, consumed at home, Thursday 20th September 2012  Pours light gold with slim white head, fresh grapefruit nose, slight haze. Buzzy tingle on the tongue, refreshing and tasty, pithy, great beer.  Tart, tangy refreshing grapefruit, lovely, lovely beer.  A8 A4 T8 P4 Ov16  4.0   Had this again this time on cask, handpump at The Well and Bucjet, Shoreditch, London, Saturday 18th January 2014  Pours warm gold with a slim white head, the nose is great its citrussy with some grapefruit but also a light tropical touch. A lovely juicy and wonderfully hoppy beer this would get another 4.0 were it not for the fact it is served just a tad warm.  A7 A4 T8 P4 Ov15  3.8  Combined mark now  3.9
botle at home ... golden amber ... thin white head ... soft floral orange ... light zezt nose... dry orange and passsion fruit ...  little passion fruit in linger

Cask at the Euston Tap, London. Pours clear yellow with a sturdy, white foam head. Lots of grainy, toasty-grassy hops in the nose, some toasty bread, some very mild citrus notes. Light to medium sweet, some toast, grain, lots of bitter earth, dirt and grass, a bit of orange rind. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Gritty bitter finish, faintly abrasive with dirt, heavy grass, earth, very faint tangy lemon. A characterful beer, but just a touch too aggressive in terms of the bitterness.
500ml bottle at 3.9%.  Pours light gold with a large head.  Aroma is subtle, lime and mango.  Taste has a little lime to start with a very bitter, earthy finish.

Bottle.  Hazy gold with a pillow of white foam.  Aromas are biscuit malts with fresh grassy notes and light grapefruit.  Creamy oak and hints of pine with marmalade.  Flavours are bittersweet grapefruit and oranges with dry woodiness.  Biscuit malts with prickly nettle.  Grassy, crisp and addictive with spritzy yeast.  Has a long bitter finish.  Really nice.

Cask gravity @ Battersea BF 2012. Pours a clear golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity peppery hoppy citrus aroma. Fruity malty hoppy bitter citrus flavor. Has a fruity malty peppery hoppy citrus finish.

Cask gravity, Derby Winter BF, 17/02/12. Pale and pretty much headless. Resinous pine and lemon aroma. Dry and stinging with grapefruit IBUs over a rock solid, pale husky base. Rich tea in stewed Darjeeling afters. Not what I was expecting from Nelson.

Bottle from Great Grog. Pours a blonde colour with a decent white head. Lovely Nelson Sauvin aroma of grapefruit and passionfruit. Foamy mouth-feel with grapefruit and passionfruit flavours. Moderate carbonation and fairly bitter. Nicely done and very tasty for the abv.
From DantheMan, thanks! Bottle. Blonde. Grapefruit and lemon in the aroma. Firm grassy earthy hopbitter flavor with lemon and grapefruit. Long earthy grassy bitter aftertaste. Lovely ale.
Now Thats What I Call Hops 2.  Pours a cloudy pale yellow.  with a thin head.  lovely zesty aroma.  Lemon and hops.  Nice.

Bottle from Great Grog. Pours a slightly murky (whoops)dirty yellow, with a good white head that stays around. Beautiful Nelson nose - grape, apple, tropical fruits. Dry hoppy, slightly bready palate, with a lingering zesty bitterness that punches well above its ABV weight. Fantastic beer.

Cask-conditioned at Mr Foleys Ale House, Leeds 23/06/09. Deep gold in colour with a decent white head. Grapefruit and pineapple hop aroma. Slightly prickly mouth feel, with grapefruit and gooseberry flavours leading to a resiny dry finish. Very good.
